1.subquestion: Which of the vertices $A, B, C, D, E,$ and $F$ have the shortest distance to $P$?

subanswer.text: Based on the given information, vertices $C$ and $D$ have equal shortest distance to $P$ which is $3$ units. Similarly, vertices $A$ and $E$ also have equal shortest distance to $P$ which is $8$ units. But neither $C$ nor $D$ nor $A$ nor $E$ can possibly have the same shortest distance to $P$ as all the other vertices except itself. So no vertex has the shortest distance to $P$ among all the vertices. The answer is no vertex has the shortest distance to $P$ among all the vertices.

- $(X,E)\quad XE^2=(1.2-0)^2+(1.5-1)^2=0.64\quad XE=0.8$
